title: Falling for your best friend? Here's what to do
text:
Next Story : Indian women are running up a storm!

He’s your confidante and your voice of reason. He cracks a joke; you snigger and smack the back of his head. You know you can count on him and he’s the only one who can uplift your spirits. And in one Eureka moment, you realise you’ve not only fallen for him, but also run the risk of ruining the friendship because he may not see you the same way. Having feelings for your best friend can be maddening! The frustration of not being able to embrace your emotions only makes it worse. “You have to be careful and analytical in such situations. Before taking any step, ask yourself whether it really is a good match?” asks Dr Shefali Batra, senior consultant psychiatrist and cognitive therapist, founder of Mindframes and co-founder of Innerhour. We’re here to help. Read on to explore a four-point plan you can follow.Is there a spark? People often read into situations that are non-existent, thanks to the rose-coloured glasses they slip on every time they have a crush. In this case, the risk of losing a friend is real and must be taken into consideration. While the concept of chemistry might be different for all, there are common signs that are suggestive of it. Dialogues laced with slightly sexual quips, double entendres, romantic connotations, and subtle expressions of what it might be like if the two of you met in a different scenario, along with slight physical contact are all indications that there is chemistry from the other side as well. Based on these signs you will know whether or not to go ahead and pursue this person, says Dr Batra.Find ways to engage through conversation. It need not be openly flirtatious; it could be as simple as discussing your favourite flavour of ice cream or a movie, advises Dr Batra. Compliment him, but be sincere. If the conversation flows and he responds to your subtle flirting positively, the ball is in your court. “In my experience, chatting over dinner was quite insightful. We discussed dating, kicking off with ridiculous dates we’ve experienced to understanding his perspective on love. The secret lies in gently toeing the line backed up by good conversation and subtle flirting. It’s what helped my current boyfriend and I transform a healthy friendship into a healthy romance.” shares Kavya Gunani, a 26-year-old IT professional from Gurgaon.A gentle reminder: Focus on yourself. Don’t obsess over your crush or let your feelings consume you. While taking up a spin class or grabbing a drink with your pals are superficial distractions and we encourage them; remind yourself that it’s not real until both parties are equally invested. What’s the point of fretting until then? Let things unravel naturally. Don’t make yourself available all the time. Leave him to stew in his own thoughts after you’ve subtly shown interest. It just might intrigue him. Allow him to discover what it feels like to miss you. Intervals of space will give him the opportunity to appreciate your presence when you two do decide to hang out. Dr Seema Hingorany, independent clinical psychologist and author, “Focus on your own life goals and avoid behaving desperate and clingy. Work on your obsessive patterns if any. Clinginess is a major turn off for most men and it robs you of your dignity.” Self-respect is key.It’s time to let him know how you feel about him. The turmoil that comes with denying your feelings is far greater than that of putting yourself out there. So let it out. Communicate your feelings and be open about your intentions. Being candid instead of playing mind games is refreshing. Put your cards on the table for him to see; being vulnerable in such situations doesn’t translate to being weak. But know where to draw the line. “I shared a very special bond with my best friend who I liked romantically. But being in the middle of a one-sided romance can be disquieting.I chose to isolate from him for a while to get my bearings. I was gradually able to move on; time fixes everything.” says Rochelle D’souza, a 28-year-old dentist living in Mumbai. “Be clear that you’re looking for a relationship, and if he isn’t ready then he’s not for you. Don’t waste your time if being his ‘friend’ feels like you’re actually just an emotional sounding board.” If it works, there’s nothing like it. Take it slow and let the romance blossom naturally. If he doesn’t feel the same way, it’s time to take a step back. Affections cannot be forced. It’s a mark of maturity to accept the reality of the situation and move on. Take some time off from his company if you feel the need to. Always remember, it’s not the end of the world. There are plenty of fish in the sea; take the plunge when you’re ready again.123rf
description: While the feeling is tempting, it can get exasperating soon enough. Read on to explore a four-point plan you can follow if you fall for your best friend.
